garments.name: Single-Breasted Suit Jacket
garments.description: Classic suit jacket with single row of buttons and overlapping front panels
garments.construction_details: Structured with canvas interlining, pad-stitched lapels, functional buttonholes on sleeves. Features chest pocket, flap pockets, and interior pockets. Shoulder construction can be natural, roped, or padded.
garments.key_features: Notch or peak lapels, 1-3 button configurations (2-button most common), center vent or side vents, structured shoulders
garments.historical_context: Evolved from military and riding coats in the 19th century. The modern single-breasted jacket became standard business wear in the 20th century.
garments.styling_tips: Two-button jackets are most versatile for business. Button only top button when standing. Jacket should lightly touch shoulders when worn. Sleeve should show 1-1.5cm of shirt cuff.

garments.name: Double-Breasted Jacket
garments.description: Formal jacket with two parallel columns of buttons and wide overlap
garments.construction_details: Similar construction to single-breasted but with wider front overlap requiring additional fabric. Peak lapels most common. Requires precise balance and button placement.
garments.key_features: 4-6 buttons (typically 6x2 or 4x2 configuration), peak lapels, wider front overlap, more formal appearance
garments.historical_context: Originally naval and military wear. Became civilian formal wear in 1930s-40s. Experienced resurgence in 1980s and contemporary fashion.
garments.styling_tips: Keep buttoned when standing (unlike single-breasted). Best worn by taller individuals due to visual weight. Extremely formal and authoritative appearance.

garments.name: Dress Shirt
garments.description: Formal shirt designed to be worn with suits or under jackets
garments.construction_details: Constructed from cotton or cotton-blend poplin or broadcloth. Features collar construction with interfacing, button placket, barrel or French cuffs, yoke for shoulder shaping.
garments.key_features: Collar and cuffs designed to be worn with ties and jackets, longer tail for tucking, formal button placket
garments.historical_context: Evolved from undergarments to become essential business wear. White dress shirt remains the most formal option.
garments.styling_tips: White and light blue are most versatile colors. Collar should fit with room for two fingers. Cuffs should extend 1-1.5cm beyond jacket sleeve.

garments.name: Dress Trousers
garments.description: Formal pants designed to pair with suit jackets or blazers
garments.construction_details: Tailored fit through waist, hips, and legs. Features include waistband with hook-and-bar closure, belt loops or side adjusters, front pleats (optional), back pockets, crease pressed down center front and back.
garments.key_features: Can be flat-front or pleated, break determines length, cuffs optional, typically wool or wool-blend
garments.historical_context: Separated from suit concept in mid-20th century allowing mix-and-match business attire. Pleats more traditional, flat-front more modern.
garments.styling_tips: Length should create slight break on shoes for formal wear, no break for modern slim fit. Pleats should lay flat when standing.

garments.name: Blazer
garments.description: Structured jacket in solid color or pattern, less formal than suit jacket
garments.construction_details: Similar construction to suit jacket but often unlined or half-lined. May have metal buttons (naval style) or standard buttons. Less rigid structuring than formal suits.
garments.key_features: Patch pockets common, metal buttons optional, navy blue most traditional, can be worn with non-matching trousers
garments.historical_context: Originated from British navy jackets. Became preppy American staple in mid-20th century. Now bridge between formal and casual wear.
garments.styling_tips: Navy blazer with grey trousers is classic combination. Can be dressed up with tie or down without. Versatile for business casual environments.

garments.name: Overcoat
garments.description: Long formal coat worn over suits for warmth in cold weather
garments.construction_details: Constructed from heavy wool, often with lining and possible interlining for warmth. Extends below knee for traditional style, mid-thigh for modern cuts. Set-in sleeves with room for layering.
garments.key_features: Full-length (past knee), formal appearance, structured shoulders, often features back vent for movement
garments.historical_context: Essential garment of 19th and early 20th centuries before heated transportation. Remains formal cold-weather outerwear.
garments.styling_tips: Should have room to layer suit jacket underneath comfortably. Charcoal, navy, and camel are most versatile colors. Length depends on height and proportion.

garments.name: Waistcoat/Vest
garments.description: Sleeveless garment worn over shirt and under jacket in three-piece suits
garments.construction_details: Tailored to fit closely to torso. Back typically lined silk or satin with adjustable strap for fit. Front matches suit fabric. Five or six buttons typical.
garments.key_features: No collar (typically), V-neck front, adjustable back strap, formal or casual depending on styling
garments.historical_context: Originally called waistcoat in UK, vest in US. Part of classic three-piece suit. Became optional in 20th century casual evolution.
garments.styling_tips: Bottom button traditionally left unbuttoned. Should cover waistband completely when standing. Can be worn without jacket in business casual settings.
